yoruba: A mọ wí pé Sean àti àwọn àádọ́ta-ọ̀kẹ́ bíi tiẹ̀ káàkiri orílẹ̀-èdè náà lẹ́tọ̀ọ́ láti ní gbogbo nǹkan tí ayé yìí ní láti fúnni, láìjẹ́pé àìdọ́gda yóò ma jàwọ́n lólè irú àǹfààní yẹn.

english: All the result of racism and historical and systemic underinvestment are now compounded by COVID-19.
yoruba: Gbogbo èsi ẹlẹ́yàmẹyà ìtàn àti ètò àìdókòwò ti wá papọ̀ mọ́ COVID-19.

english: Our comprehensive model uniquely positions the Harlem Children's Zone in the fight of COVID.
yoruba: Èkúnrẹ́rẹ́ àwòṣe wa gbé Harlem Children’s Zone sínu ìjàgùdu COVID lọ́nà ọ̀tọ̀.

english: The success that we have on the ground in Harlem makes it imperative, and it is our responsibility to share what we know works with the country.
yoruba: Àṣeyọrí tí a ní lọ́pọ̀ ní Harlem sọ ó di pàtàkì, ojúṣe wa sì ni láti sọ ohun tí a mọ̀ pé ó ṣiṣe fún orílè-èdè.

english: We have developed a comprehensive COVID-19 relief and recovery response for our community, that was surfaced from our community, focused on five primary areas of need, and already servicing families like Sean's.
yoruba: A ti ṣe àgbékalẹ̀ ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ ìdáhùn sí ìdẹ̀rùn àti ìpadàbọ̀-sípò COVID-19 fún àwùjọ wa, tí ó jẹyọ ní àwùjọ wa, tó dálé àwọn kókó nǹkan kòṣeémánìí márùn-ún, a sì ń ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún àwọn ẹbí bíi ti Sean.

english: They are the following.
yoruba: Àwọn náà rè é.

english: One, emergency relief funds.
yoruba: Àkọ́kọ́, owó ìdẹ̀run pàjáwírì.

english: We know that our families need cash in their hands right now.
yoruba: A mọ̀ wí pé àwọn ẹbí wa nílò owó lọ́wọ́ wọn lásíkò yìí.

english: Two, protecting our most vulnerable.
yoruba: Ìkejì, dídáààbò bo àwọn akọ́gun-séwujù wa.

english: We know our families need access to essential goods and information.
yoruba: A mọ̀ wí pé àwọn ẹbí wa nílò àǹfààní sí àwọn ohun-èlo-kòṣeémánì àti ìfitónilétí.

english: So that is food, that's masks, that's a curated resource list and public health campaigns.
yoruba: Oúnjẹ nìyẹn, ìbòmú nìyẹn, àkójọpọ̀ ohun-èlò àti ìpolongo ìlera gbogbogbò.

english: Three, bridging the digital divide.
yoruba: Ìkẹ́ta, dídí àlàfo àìdọ́gba àrọ́wọ́tó ẹ̀rọ- ayélukára.

english: We believe that internet is a fundamental right.
yoruba: A nígbàgbọ́ wí pé ẹ̀tọ kòṣeémánì ni ẹ̀rọ̀-ayélukára jẹ́.

english: So we need to ensure our families have connectivity, and also all school-age children in a household have the proper learning devices.
yoruba: A ní láti ríi dájú wí pé àwọn ẹbí wa ní ìsopọ̀ mọ́ ẹ̀rọ-ayélukára, bákan náà gbogbo àwọn ọmọ tí ọjọ́-orí wọ́n wà lábẹ́ ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ní ilé kan ni wọ́n ní ohun-èlò ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ tó tọ́.

english: Four, zero learning loss.
yoruba: Ìkẹ́rin, àìpàdánù ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́.

english: We know that there's a generation of students at risk of losing an entire year of their education.
yoruba: A mọ̀ wí pé àwọn ìran akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ kan wà tí wọ́n wà nínú ewu ìpàdánù gbogbo ọdún ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ wọn.

english: We need to make sure that we are providing high-quality virtual programing, in addition to having safe reentry planned for school reentry.
yoruba: A nílò láti ríi wí pé à ń pèsè ètò ìkẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ẹrọ-ayélukára tó lágbára, ní àfikún sí ṣíṣe ètò ìpadàwọlé aláìléwu fún ìpadàwọlé ilé-ẹ̀kọ́.

english: And five, mitigating the mental health crisis.
yoruba: Ìkarùn-ún, mímú àdínkù bá àrùn ọpọlọ.

english: There's a generation at risk of having PTSD, due to the massive amounts of toxic stress.
yoruba: Àwọn ìran kan wà nínú ewu níní PTSD, nítorí àpọ̀jù májèlé ti láàláà.

english: We need to ensure that our families have access to telehealth and other virtual supports.
yoruba: A nílò láti ríi dájú pé àwọn ẹbí wa ní àǹfààní sí ètò-ìlera orí ẹ̀rọ ayélukára àti àwọn ìrànlọ́wọ́ orí ẹ̀rọ-ayélukára mìíràn.

english: We have six amazing partners across six cities in the United States that are adopting our model for their own context in their community.
yoruba: A ní àwọn alájọṣepọ̀ tó dantọ́ mẹ́fà káàkiri àwọn ìletò mẹ́fà ní orílẹ̀-ède United States tí wọ́n ń tẹ̀lé àwòṣe wa fún ọ̀gangan-ipò tiwọn ní àwùjọ wọn.

english: They are Oakland, Minneapolis, Chicago, Detroit, Newark and Atlanta.
yoruba: Àwọn náà ni Oakland, Minneapolis, Chicago, Detroit, Newark àti Atlanta.

english: In addition to those partners, we have three national partners, who will be sharing our model and sharing our strategies through their network, in addition to amplifying our impact by policy advocacy.
yoruba: Ní àfikún sí àwọn alájọṣepọ̀ wọ̀nyẹn, a ní àwọn alájọṣepọ̀ orílẹ̀-èdè mẹ́ta, tí wọ́n yóò ma pín àwòṣe wa àti àwọn èto wa lórí ìkàni wọn, ní àfikún sí pípariwo ipa wa pẹ̀lú àtìlẹ́yìn ìpinnu.

english: We will have impact on three levels.
yoruba: A máa ní ipa ní ìpele mẹ́ta.

english: Individual impact on the ground in Harlem, across a number of outcomes in education, in health, in economics, reaching 30,000 people.
yoruba: Ipa ẹnìkọ̀ọ̀kan lọ́pọ̀ ní Harlem, káàkiri iye àwọn àbájáde nínú ètò-ẹ̀kọ́, nínú ètò-ìlera, nínú ọrọ̀-ajé, kíkànsí ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà 30 àwọn ènìyàn.

english: There's community-level impact across six cities, again through our amazing partners, that will reach an additional 70,000 people.
yoruba: Ipa ìpele àwùjọ náà wà káàkiri àwọn ìletò mẹ́fà, bákan náà nípasẹ̀ àwọn alájọṣepọ̀ wa tó dántọ́, tí wọ́n yóò kàn sí àfikún ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà 70 àwọn ènìyàn.

english: And then national impact, not only through policy advocacy, but through capacity building at scale.
yoruba: Lẹ́yìn náà ipa lórí orílẹ̀ èdè, kì í ṣe nípa ìgbawí ìlànà-ìṣe nìkan, ṣùgbọ́n nípasẹ̀ mím ìronilagbara de ojú ìwọ̀n.

english: Our answer to COVID-19, the despair and inequities plaguing our communities, is targeting neighborhoods with comprehensive services.
yoruba: Ìdáhùn wa sí COVID-19, àìnírètí àti àìdọ́gba tó ń bá àwùjọ wa jà, ń dojú kọ àwọn àdúgbò pẹ̀lú ẹ̀kúnrẹ́rẹ́ iṣẹ́.

english: We have certainly not lost hope.
yoruba: A ò tíì sọ ìrètí nù rárá.

english: And we invite you to join us on the front lines of this war.
yoruba: A sì ń pè yín láti darapọ̀ mọ́ wa níwáju ogun yìí.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: Why civilians suffer more once a war is over
yoruba: Ìdí tí ìyà ṣe máa ń jẹ àwọn ará-ìlú gan-an nígbà tí ogún bá ti parí.

english: So have you ever wondered what it would be like to live in a place with no rules?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ o ti rò ó tẹ́lẹ̀ rí pé báwo ló ṣe máa rí tí enìyán bá ń gbé níbi tí kò sí òfin.

english: That sounds pretty cool.
yoruba: Ìyẹ́n dùn gbọ́.

english: You wake up one morning, however, and you discover that the reason there are no rules is because there's no government, and there are no laws.
yoruba: O jí láàrọ̀ ọjọ́ kan, ẹ̀wẹ̀, ẹ wá rí i wí pé ìdí tí kò fi sí òfin ni wí pé kò sí ìjọba, kò sì sí òfin.

english: In fact, all social institutions have disappeared.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, gbogbo ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ ti pòórá.

english: So there's no schools, there's no hospitals, there's no police, there's no banks, there's no athletic clubs, there's no utilities.
yoruba: Nítorí náà Kò sí ilé-ẹ̀kọ́, kò sí ilé-ìwòsàn, kò sí ọlọ́pàá, kò sí ilé-ìfowópamọ́, kò sí àwọn ẹgbẹ́ eléré-ìdárayá, kò sí ohun-èlò.

english: Well, I know a little bit about what this is like, because when I was a medical student in 1999, I worked in a refugee camp in the Balkans during the Kosovo War.
yoruba: Ó dáa. Mo mọ díẹ̀ nípa bí èyí ṣe rí, torí nígbà tí mo jẹ́ akẹ́kọ̀ọ́ ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn ní odún 1999, mo ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìpàgọ́ àwọn atìpó ní Balkans lásìko ogun Kosovo.

english: When the war was over, I got permission -- unbelievably -- from my medical school to take some time off and follow some of the families that I had befriended in the camp back to their village in Kosovo, and understand how they navigated life in this postwar setting.
yoruba: Nígbà tí ogun náà parí, mo gba ìyànda -- sí ìyàlẹ́nu -- láti ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ ìmọ̀-ìṣègùn mi láti lọ sinmi kí n sì tẹ̀lé àwọn ẹbí tí mo ti bá dọ́rẹ̀ẹ́ ní ìpàgọ́ náà padà sí abúlé wọn ní Kosovo, kí n mo bí wọn yóò ṣe lo ìgbésí-ayé ní ibùdó léyìn ogun yìí.

english: Postwar Kosovo was a very interesting place because NATO troops were there, mostly to make sure the war didn't break out again.
yoruba: Kosovo léyìn ogun jẹ́ ibìkan tó dùn nítorí àwọn ọmọ-ogun NATO wà níbẹ̀, láti rí i pé ogun ò tún ṣẹ́yọ mọ́.

english: But other than that, it was actually a lawless place, and almost every social institution, both public and private, had been destroyed.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n yàtọ̀ sí ìyẹn, àyè tí ò l’ófin ni, ó fẹ́rẹ̀ jẹ́ pé gbogbo ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ, ti ìjọba àti aládàni, ni wọ́n ti bàjẹ́.

english: So I can tell you that when you go into one of these situations and settings, it is absolutely thrilling for about 30 minutes, because that's about how long it takes before you run into a situation where you realize how incredibly vulnerable you are.
yoruba: Nítorí náà mo lè sọ fún yín wí pé tí ẹ bá wọ ọ̀kan nínú àwọn ipò àti ibùdó yìí, ó máa ń panilẹ́rìn-ín fún bíi ọgbọ̀n ìṣẹ́jú, torí bó ṣe máa ń pẹ́ tó nìyẹn kí ẹ tó wà ní ipò tí ẹ ó fi mọ bí ẹ ṣe kángun-séwu sí.

english: For me, that moment came when I had to cross the first checkpoint, and I realized as I drove up that I would be negotiating passage through this checkpoint with a heavily armed individual who, if he decided to shoot me right then and there, actually wouldn't be doing anything illegal.
yoruba: Fún èmi, àkókò náà wá nígbà tí mo ní láti kọjá ẹnu-ibodè àkọ́kọ́, bí mo ṣe wa ọkọ̀ síwájú ni mo ti mọ̀ wí pé mo máa ṣe ìdúnàádúrà kíkọjá ẹnu-ibodè yìí pẹ̀lú ẹnìkàn tó dìhá ogun tó ṣe pé, tó bá pinnu láti yìnbọ mọ́mi lásíkò yẹn àti níbẹ̀ yẹn, kò ní tíì ṣe nǹkan tí ò bófinmu.

english: But the sense of vulnerability that I had was absolutely nothing in comparison to the vulnerability of the families that I got to know over that year.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n òye ìkángun-séwu tí mo ní kò tó nǹkan sí ìkángun-séwu àwọn ẹbí tí mo mò ní ọdún yẹn.

english: You see, life in a society where there are no social institutions is riddled with danger and uncertainty, and simple questions like, "What are we going to eat tonight?" are very complicated to answer.
yoruba: Ṣẹ ẹ rí i, ìgbe-ayé láwùjọ tí kò sí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ ń kojú ewu àti àìdájú, àti àwọn ìbéèrè tó rọrùn bíi, “kí la máa jẹ lálẹ́ yìí? “jẹ́ àmúdijú láti dáhùn.

english: Questions about security, when you don't have any security systems, are terrifying.
yoruba: Àwọn ìbéèrè nípa ààbò, nígbà tí kò bá sí ètò ààbò, máa ń bani lẹ́rù.

english: Is that altercation I had with the neighbor down the block going to turn into a violent episode that will end my life or my family's life?
yoruba: Ṣé èdè-àìyedè yẹn tí mo ní pẹ̀lu aráalé mi tó wà nísálẹ̀ ò ní di rògbòdìyàn tí yóò gba èmí mi tàbí èmi ẹbí mi?

english: Health concerns when there is no health system are also terrifying.
yoruba: Ìrònú nípa ìlere nígbà tí kò bá sí ètò-ìlera náà ń bani lẹ́rù.

english: I listened as many families had to sort through questions like, "My infant has a fever.
yoruba: Mo ń tẹ́ti bí ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn ẹbí ṣe ní láti yanjú àwọn ìbéèrè bi, “ìkókó mi ní ààrun ibà.

english: What am I going to do?
yoruba: Kíni mo fẹ́ ṣe?

english: " "My sister, who is pregnant, is bleeding.
yoruba: “ ”Àbúrò mi lóbìrin, tó lóyún, ń da ẹ̀jẹ̀.

english: What should I do?
yoruba: Kíni kí n ṣe?

english: Who should I turn to?
yoruba: Tani kí n kọjú sí?

english: " "Where are the doctors, where are the nurses?
yoruba: “ “Àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó dà, àwọn olùtọ́-ilé-ìwòsàn dà?

english: If I could find one, are they trustworthy?
yoruba: Tí mo bá lè ri ọ̀kan, ṣé wọ́n ṣe é gbàgbọ́?

english: How will I pay them?
yoruba: Báwo ni màá ṣe sanwó fún wọn?

english: In what currency will I pay them?
yoruba: Irú owó wo ni màá fi sanwó fún wọn?

english: " "If I need medications, where will I find them?
yoruba: “ “Tí mo bá nílò òògùn, níbo ni màá ti rí wọn?

english: If I take those medications, are they actually counterfeits?
yoruba: Bí mo bá lo àwọn òògùn wọ̀nyẹn, ṣé ayédèrú niwọ́n lóòótọ́?

english: " And on and on.
yoruba: “ Àti bẹ́ẹ̀ àti bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: So for life in these settings, the dominant theme, the dominant feature of life, is the incredible vulnerability that people have to manage day in and day out, because of the lack of social systems.
yoruba: Fún ìgbé-ayé ní àwọn ibùdó wọ̀nyí, kókó ọ̀rọ̀ tó gbajúmọ̀ jù, àwòmọ́ ìgbeayé tó gbajúmọ̀ jù, ni ìkángun-séwu tí àwọn ènìyàn ní láti mójútó lójoojúmọ́, torí àìsí àwọn ètò àwùjọ.

english: And it actually turns out that this feature of life is incredibly difficult to explain and be understood by people who are living outside of it.
yoruba: Ó padà jẹyọ wí pé àwòmọ́ ìgbe-ayé yìí ṣòro púpọ̀ láti ṣàlàyé àti láti mọ̀ fún àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń gbé níta rẹ̀.

english: I discovered this when I left Kosovo.
yoruba: Mo mọ èyí nígbà tí mo kúrò ní Kosovo.

english: I came back to Boston, I became a physician, I became a global public health policy researcher.
yoruba: Mo padà wá sí Boston, mo di alágbàwò, mo di oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí ìpinnu ìlera gbogbogbò lágbàyé.

english: I joined the Harvard Medical School and Brigham and Women's Hospital Division of Global Health.
yoruba: Mo darapọ̀ mọ́ ilé-ẹ̀kọ́ ìṣègun Havard àti Brigham àti ẹ̀ka ilé-ìwòsàn àwọn obìnrin ti ìlera àgbáyé.

english: And I, as a researcher, really wanted to get started on this problem right away.
yoruba: Èmi, gẹ́gẹ́ bí oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí, fẹ́ bẹ́rẹ̀ iṣẹ́ lórí ìṣòro yìí lẹ́sẹ̀kẹsẹ̀.

english: I was like, "How do we reduce the crushing vulnerability of people living in these types of fragile settings?
yoruba: Mo ń rò ó wí pé, “Báwo ni a ṣe lè mú àdínkù bá ìkángun-séwu àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n ń gbé ní àwọn ibùdó ẹlẹgẹ́ wọ̀nyí?

english: Is there any way we can start to think about how to protect and quickly recover the institutions that are critical to survival, like the health system?
yoruba: Ǹjẹ́ ọ̀nà kankan wà tí a lè bẹ̀rẹ̀ síní ronú nípa bí a ṣe lè pèse ìdáààbòbo àti ìpadàbọ̀sípò lọ́gán àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ṣe pàtàkì fún ìmóríbọ́, bí ètò ìlera?

english: " And I have to say, I had amazing colleagues.
yoruba: “ Mo sì gbọ́dọ̀ sọ wí pé, mo ní àwọn akẹgbẹ́ tó dántọ́.

english: But one interesting thing about it was, this was sort of an unusual question for them.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan kan tó panilẹ́rìn nípa rẹ̀ ni wí pé, àwọn ìbéèrè àjòjì ni èyí jẹ́ fún wọn.

english: They were kind of like, "Oh, if you work in war, doesn't that mean you work on refugee camps, and you work on documenting mass atrocities?" -- which is, by the way, very, very, very important.
yoruba: “ Wọ́n rò ó wí pé, “Oh, tí ẹ bá ṣiṣẹ́ nínú ogun, ṣé ìyẹ́n ò túmọ̀ sí wí pé ẹ ṣiṣẹ́ ní ìpàgọ́ àwọn atìpó ni, ẹ sì ń ṣiṣẹ́ lórí àkọsílẹ̀ ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ìwa-ìbàjẹ́?” -- tó ṣe wí pé, lápá kan, ó ṣe pàtàkì gigi gaan.

english: So it took me a while to explain why I was so passionate about this issue, until about six years ago.
yoruba: Ó gbàmí lásíkò díẹ̀ láti ṣàlàye ìdí tí mo fi nífẹ̀ sí ọrọ̀ yìí, títí di bí ọdún mẹ́fà sẹ́yìn.

english: That's when this landmark study that looked at and described the public health consequences of war was published.
yoruba: Nígbà náà ni ìwádìí aláìlẹ́gbẹ́ yìí tó ṣe ìbojúwò àti àpèjúwe èt ò ìlera gbogbogbò àbájáde ogun di títẹ̀ jáde.

english: They came to an incredible, provocative conclusion.
yoruba: Wọ́n ṣe ìfẹnukò tó yani lẹ́nu t’ó sì bíni nínú.

english: These researchers concluded that the vast majority of death and disability from war happens after the cessation of conflict.
yoruba: Àwọn oníṣẹ́ ìwádìí wọ̀nyí fẹnukò pé ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ikú àti ìsọnidaláààbọ̀-ara látara ogun máa ń ṣẹlẹ̀ lẹ́yìn tí ìkọlura bá ti dópin.

english: So the most dangerous time to be a person living in a conflict-affected state is after the cessation of hostilities; it's after the peace deal has been signed.
yoruba: Àsìkò t’ó léwu jù láti jẹ́ ènìyàn tó ń gbé ní orílẹ̀-èdè tó ní ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀-ìkọlura ni lẹ́yìn tí ogun bá ti dópin; lẹ́yìn tí àdéhùn àlàáfíà bá ti di bíbuwọ́lù ni.

english: It's when that political solution has been achieved.
yoruba: Ìgbà tí ọ̀nà-àbáyọ òṣèlú yẹn bá ti di ṣíṣe.

english: That seems so puzzling, but of course it's not, because war kills people by robbing them of their clinics, of their hospitals, of their supply chains.
yoruba: Ìyẹn dàbi ẹní rújú, ṣùgbọ́n bẹ́ẹ̀ ni kò rí bẹ́ẹ̀, nítorí ogun máa ń pa àwọn ènìyàn nípa jíjà wọ́n lólè àwọn ilé-ìwòsan alábọ́ọ́dé wọn, àwọn ilé-ìwòsan wọn, àti ìpínkárí àwọn ẹrù-ọjà wọn.

english: Their doctors are targeted, are killed; they're on the run.
yoruba: Wọ́n máa ń dájúsọ àwọn oníṣègùn-òyìnbo wọn, wọ́n ń gba ẹ̀míi wọ́n; wọ́n ti sá lọ̀.

english: And more invisible and yet more deadly is the destruction of the health governance institutions and their finances.
yoruba: Èyí àìhàn dáadáa tí ò tún sì ń ṣekú pani jù ni ìparun àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tó ń darí ètò ìlera àti àwọn ìṣúná owó wọn.

english: So this is really not surprising at all to me.
yoruba: Torí náà èyí kò fi bẹ́ẹ̀ yà mí lẹ́nu rárá.

english: But what is surprising and somewhat dismaying, is how little impact this insight has had, in terms of how we think about human suffering and war.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n nǹkan tó yani lẹ́nu tó sì bani lọ́kan jẹ́, ni ipa kékeré tí òye yìí ní, nípa bí a ṣe ń ronú nípa ìnira àwọn ènìyàn àti ogun.

english: Let me give you a couple examples.
yoruba: Ẹ jẹ́ kí n fún yín ní àwọn àpẹẹrẹ bíi mélòó kan.

english: Last year, you may remember, Ebola hit the West African country of Liberia.
yoruba: Lọ́dún tó kọjá, ẹ lè rántí, Ebólà kọlu orílẹ̀-ède Liberia ti Ìwò-oòrùn Ilẹ̀-Adúláwọ̀.

english: There was a lot of reporting about this group, Doctors Without Borders, sounding the alarm and calling for aid and assistance.
yoruba: Ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìròyìn l’ó wà nípa ẹgbẹ́ yìí, Àwọn Oníṣégùn-Òyìnbó Láìsí Ààlà, tí wọ́n ń kébòsí tí wọ́n sì ń pè fún ìrànlọ́wọ́ àti àtìlẹyìn.

english: But not a lot of that reporting answered the question: Why is Doctors Without Borders even in Liberia?
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kì í ṣe gbogbo ìjábọ̀ ìròyìn yẹn ni ó dáhùn ìbéèrè náà: kín ni ìdí tí Àwọn Oníṣégùn-Òyìnbó Láìsí Ààlà ṣe wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Liberia?

english: Doctors Without Borders is an amazing organization, dedicated and designed to provide emergency care in war zones.
yoruba: Àwọn Oníṣégùn-Òyìnbó Láìsí Ààlà jẹ́ ilé-iṣẹ́ aláràagbàídá, tí gbékalẹ̀ t’ó sì ní ìfọkànsìn láti pèse ìtọ́júu pàjáwírì ní àwọn agbègbe ogun.

english: Liberia's civil war had ended in 2003 -- that was 11 years before Ebola even struck.
yoruba: Ogun abẹ́lé orílẹ̀-ède Liberia ti dópin ní ọdún 2003 – ìyẹn jẹ́ ọdún 11 kí arun Ebola ó tó bẹ́ sílẹ̀.

english: When Ebola struck Liberia, there were less than 50 doctors in the entire country of 4.5 million people.
yoruba: Nígbà tí Ebola bẹ́ sílẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Liberia, àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó tó dín ní 50 ni wọ́n wà ní gbogbo orílẹ̀-èdè tí ó ní àwọn ènìyàn bí ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún 4.5.

english: Doctors Without Borders is in Liberia because Liberia still doesn't really have a functioning health system, 11 years later.
yoruba: Àwọn Oníṣégùn-Òyìnbó Láìsí Ààlà wà ní orílẹ̀-ède Liberia nítorí Liberia ò tíì fi bẹ́ẹ̀ ní ètò ìlera tó ń ṣiṣẹ́ b’ó ṣe yẹ, lẹ́yìn ọdún 11.

english: When the earthquake hit Haiti in 2010, the outpouring of international aid was phenomenal.
yoruba: Nígbà tí ìṣẹ́lẹ̀ kọlu Haiti ní ọdún 2010, àwọn àtìlẹyìn tó ń wọlé láti ilẹ̀-òkèèrè kàmàmà.

english: But did you know that only two percent of that funding went to rebuild Haitian public institutions, including its health sector?
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n ṣé ẹ mọ̀ wí pé ìdá méjì ìgbọ̀wọ́ yẹn ló lọ sí kíkọ́ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìjọba gbogbogbò Haiti, tó fi mọ́ ẹ̀ka ìlera rẹ̀?

english: From that perspective, Haitians continue to die from the earthquake even today.
yoruba: Láti ojú-ìwòye yẹn, àwọn Ọmọ Haiti sì ń tẹ̀síwájú láti kú nítorí ìjì-ilẹ̀ pàápàá dòní.

english: I recently met this gentleman.
yoruba: Mo pàde arákùnrin yìí láìpẹ́ yìí.

english: This is Dr. Nezar Ismet.
yoruba: Onímọ̀-ìṣègùn Nezar Ismet rè é.

english: He's the Minister of Health in the northern autonomous region of Iraq, in Kurdistan.
yoruba: Òun ni Alákòso fún Ètò-Ìlera ní agbègbè olómìnira àríwá orílẹ̀-èdè Iraq, ní Kurdistan.

english: Here he is announcing that in the last nine months, his country, his region, has increased from four million people to five million people.
yoruba: Òun rè é tó ń kéde pé ní oṣù mẹ́sàn sẹ́yìn, orílẹ̀-ède rẹ̀, agbègbe rẹ̀, ti lékún láti ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún mẹ́rin ènìyàn sí ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún ènìyàn.

english: That's a 25 percent increase.
yoruba: Àfikún ìdá 15 nìyẹn.

english: Thousands of these new arrivals have experienced incredible trauma.
yoruba: Àìmọye ẹgbẹ̀rún nínú àwọn ṣẹ̀ṣẹdé wọ̀nyí ní wọ́n ti ní ìrìrí ìpòrúru-ọkàn tí-kò-ṣe-é-gbàgbọ́.

english: His doctors are working 16-hour days without pay.
yoruba: Àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbo rẹ̀ ń ṣiṣẹ́ fún wákàtí 16 lójúmọ́ láìgbowó.

english: His budget has not increased by 25 percent; it has decreased by 20 percent, as funding has flowed to security concerns and to short-term relief efforts.
yoruba: Ìṣúná rẹ̀ ò tíì lékún pẹ̀lú ìdá 25; ó ti dínkù pẹ̀lú ìdá 20, gẹ́gẹ́ bí ìgbọ̀wọ́ ṣe ti ṣàn sí ìrònú nípa ètò-ààbò àti ìgbìyànjú ìràlọ́wọ́ onígbà kúkúrú.

english: When his health sector fails -- and if history is any guide, it will -- how do you think that's going to influence the decision making of the five million people in his region as they think about whether they should flee that type of vulnerable living situation?
yoruba: Nígbà tí ẹ̀ka-ìlera rẹ̀ bá kùnà -- tí ìtàn bá ṣe é tẹ̀lé, yóò rí bẹ́ẹ̀ -- báwo ni ẹ ṣe rò wí pé ìyẹn ṣe lè nípa lórí ṣíṣe ìpinnu fún ẹgbẹ̀rún-lọ́nà-ẹgbẹ̀rún márùn-ún àwọn ènìyàn tó wà ní agbègbe rẹ̀ bí wọ́n ṣe ń ronú nípa bóyá kí àwọ́n sá fún irú ipò ìgbéayé ìkágun-séwu bẹ́ẹ̀?

english: So as you can see, this is a frustrating topic for me, and I really try to understand: Why the reluctance to protect and support indigenous health systems and security systems?
yoruba: Gẹ́gẹ́ bí ẹ ṣe rí i, kókó-ọ̀rọ̀ tó ń dani láàmù ni èyí jẹ́ fún mi, mo sì gbìyànjú gan-an láti ní òye pé: kí ló ń fa ìsún-sẹ́yìn láti pèsè ìdáààbòbò àti ṣíṣe àtìlẹyìn ètò-ìlera ẹni àti ètò ààbò?

english: I usually tier two concerns, two arguments.
yoruba: Mo máa ń ní àníyàn méjì, àríyànjiyàn méjì.

english: The first concern is about corruption, and the concern that people in these settings are corrupt and they are untrustworthy.
yoruba: Àníyàn àkọ́kọ́ ni nípa ìwà-ìbàjẹ́, àti àníyàn wí pé àwọn ènìyàn tí wọ́n wà ní àwọn ibùdó wọ̀nyí níwà ìbàjẹ́ wọn ò sì ṣe é gbàgbọ́.

english: And I will admit that I have met unsavory characters working in health sectors in these situations.
yoruba: Mo máa gbà wí pé mo ti pàdé àwọn oníwà-ìbàjẹ́ ti wọ́n ń ṣiṣẹ́ ní ẹ̀ka-ìlera ní àwọn ipò wọ̀nyí.

english: But I will tell you that the opposite is absolutely true in every case I have worked on, from Afghanistan to Libya, to Kosovo, to Haiti, to Liberia -- I have met inspiring people, who, when the chips were down for their country, they risked everything to save their health institutions.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n mo máa sọ fún-un yín pé òótọ́ ni ìdàkejì jẹ́ nínú gbogbo nǹkan tí mo ti ṣiṣẹ́ lé lorí, láti orílẹ̀-ède Afganistan dé Libya, dé Kosovo, dé Haiti, dé Liberia -- mo ti pàdé àwọn ènìyàn tó n fúnni ní ìmísí, tó ṣe wí pé, nígbà tí ìṣòro tó lágbára bá ṣẹlẹ̀ sí orílẹ̀-ède wọn, wọn máa ń ṣe gbogbo nǹkan láti dóólà àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ìlera wọn.

english: The trick for the outsider who wants to help is identifying who those individuals are, and building a pathway for them to lead.
yoruba: Ọgbọ́n fún àwọn aráàta tí wọ́n fẹ́ ṣe ìrànlọ́wọ́ ni láti tọ́ka ẹni tí àwọn ènìyàn wọ̀nyẹn ń ṣe, kí wọ́n sì pèsè ojú-ọ̀nà fún wọn láti ṣíwájú.

english: That is exactly what happened in Afghanistan.
yoruba: Nǹkan tó ṣẹlẹ̀ ní orílẹ̀-ède Afganistan gaan nìyẹn.

english: One of the unsung and untold success stories of our nation-building effort in Afghanistan involved the World Bank in 2002 investing heavily in identifying, training and promoting Afghani health sector leaders.
yoruba: Ọ̀kan lára àwọn ìtàn àṣeyọrí ìgbìyànju kíkọ́-orílẹ̀-èdè Afganistan wa tí wọn ò sì gbóríyìn nípa rẹ̀ ni ti ìdókòwò ńlá Ilé-ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ní ọdún 2002 láti ṣèdámọ̀, ṣíṣe ìkọ́ni àti àgbéga àwọn adarí ẹ̀ka ètò-ìlera Afgani.

english: These health sector leaders have pulled off an incredible feat in Afghanistan.
yoruba: Àwọn adarí ẹ̀ka ètò-ìlera wọ̀nyí ti ṣe àṣeyọrí tó pọ̀ ní Afganistan.

english: They have aggressively increased access to health care for the majority of the population.
yoruba: Wọ́n ti fi ìkanra ṣe àfikún àǹfààní sí ìtọ́jú ìlera fún ọ̀pọ̀ àwọn ará-ìlú.

english: They are rapidly improving the health status of the Afghan population, which used to be the worst in the world.
yoruba: Wọ́n mú ìyàtọ̀ tó dáa bá ipò ìlera àwọn ènìyan Afghan, tó jẹ́ wí pé oun ló burú jùlọ lágbàáyé tẹ́lẹ̀.

english: In fact, the Afghan Ministry of Health does things that I wish we would do in America.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, ilé-iṣẹ́ tó ń rí sí ètò-ìlera ní Afghan ń ṣe àwọn nǹkan tí yóò wùn mí ká ṣe é ní orílẹ̀-ède America.

english: They use things like data to make policy.
yoruba: Wọ́n ń lo àwọn nǹkan bí ìwífúni-alálàyé láti ṣe ìpinnu.

english: It's incredible.
yoruba: Ó lágbára.

english: The other concern I hear a lot about is: "We just can't afford it, we just don't have the money.
yoruba: Àníyàn kejì tí mo máa ń gbọ́ nípa rẹ̀ gan-an ni: “Ó ti ga ju ara lọ, a ò ní owó rẹ̀.

english: It's just unsustainable.
yoruba: Kò ṣe é tẹ̀síwájú.

english: " I would submit to you that the current situation and the current system we have is the most expensive, inefficient system we could possibly conceive of.
yoruba: “ Mo máa jábọ̀ fun yín pé nǹkan tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ lọ́wọ́ àti ètò tí a ní lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ ló wọ́n jù, ohun sì ni ètò tí ò ṣiṣẹ́ tí a lè ronú rẹ̀ lọ.

english: The current situation is that when governments like the US -- or, let's say, the collection of governments that make up the European Commission -- every year, they spend 15 billion dollars on just humanitarian and emergency and disaster relief worldwide.
yoruba: Nǹkan tó ń ṣẹlẹ̀ lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ ni wí pé nígbà tí àwọn ìjọba bíi ti orílẹ̀-ède US -- tàbí, ká sọ wí pé, àkójọpọ̀ àwọn ìjọba tí wọ́n jọ parapọ̀ di Àjọ-Ìgbìmọ Ilẹ̀ Europe -- lọ́dọọdún, wọ́n ń ná bílíọ́nù mẹ́ẹ̀dógún dọ́là lórí ìdẹ̀rùn àánú ọmọnìyàn àti pàjáwírì àti àjálù jákè-jákò àgbánlá-ayé.

english: That's nothing about foreign aid, that's just disaster relief.
yoruba: Ìyẹn kìí ṣe nǹkankan nípa ìrànwọ́ ilẹ̀-òkèèrè, ìdẹ̀rùn àjálù nìkan nìyẹn o.

english: Ninety-five percent of it goes to international relief agencies, that then have to import resources into these areas, and knit together some type of temporary health system, let's say, which they then dismantle and send away when they run out of money.
yoruba: Ìdá márún-lè-láàdọ́rùn nínú rẹ̀ ni ó ń lọ sí àwọn Àjọ ìdẹ̀rùn ilẹ̀ òkèèrè, tí wọ́n ní láti kó àwọn ohun-èlò wọlé sí àwọn àgbègbè yìí, tí wọn ó sì hun àwọn ètò ìlera onígbà díẹ̀ papọ̀, ká sọ wí pé, tí wọ́n yóò wá tú u ká tí wọn yóò sì lé wọn dànù nígbà tí owó bá tán.

english: So our job, it turns out, is very clear.
yoruba: Nítorí náà iṣẹ́ wa, bó ṣe rí, hàn kedere.

english: We, as the global health community policy experts, our first job is to become experts in how to monitor the strengths and vulnerabilities of health systems in threatened situations.
yoruba: Àwa, gẹ́gẹ́ bi àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nínú ìpinnu àwùjọ ìlera àgbáyé, àkọ́kọ́ iṣẹ́ wa ni láti di àgbà-ọ̀jẹ̀ nínú bí a ṣe ń mójútó okun àti ìkọ́gun-séwu ètò ìlera ní ipò ewu.

english: And that's when we see doctors fleeing, when we see health resources drying up, when we see institutions crumbling -- that's the emergency.
yoruba: Nígbà náà ni à ń rí àwọn oníṣègùn-òyìnbó tí wọ́n ń sálọ, nígbà tí à ń rí àwọn ohun-èlò ìlera tó ń gbẹ, nígbà tí à ń rí àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ tí wọ́n ń wó -- pàjáwírì náà nìyẹn.

english: That's when we need to sound the alarm and wave our arms.
yoruba: Nígbà náà ni a gbọ́dọ̀ kébòsí kí a sì juwọ́ wa.

english: Not now.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe nísìyìí.

english: Everyone can see that's an emergency, they don't need us to tell them that.
yoruba: Gbogbo ènìyàn ló lè ri wí pé pàjáwírì nìyẹn, wọn ò nílò wa láti sọ ìyẹn fún wọn.

english: Number two: places like where I work at Harvard need to take their cue from the World Bank experience in Afghanistan, and we need to -- and we will -- build robust platforms to support health sector leaders like these.
yoruba: Ẹlẹ́ẹ̀kejì: àwọn ibi tí mo ti ṣiṣẹ́ bíi ní Havard nílò láti kọ́ ẹ̀kọ́ látara ìrírí Ilé-Ìfowópamọ́ Àgbáyé ní orílẹ̀-ède Afganistan, a sì ní láti -- a sì máa -- kọ́ àwọn igbàgede láti ṣe ìrànwọ́ fún àwọn adarí ẹ̀ka ètò-ìlera bí àwọn wọ̀nyí.

english: These people risk their lives.
yoruba: Àwọn ènìyàn wọ̀nyí ń fi ẹ̀mi ara wọn wéwu.

english: I think we can match their courage with some support.
yoruba: Mo rò wí pé a lè bá akínkanjú wọn dọ́gba pẹ̀lú àwọn ìrànlọ́wọ́ kọ̀ọ̀kan.

english: Number three: we need to reach out and make new partnerships.
yoruba: Ẹ̀lẹ́ẹ̀kẹ́ta: a nílò láti jáde síta k’á sì ṣe àwọn àjọṣepọ̀ tuntun.

english: At our global health center, we have launched a new initiative with NATO and other security policy makers to explore with them what they can do to protect health system institutions during deployments.
yoruba: Ní àwọn ibi ìlera àgbáyé wa, a ti ṣe ìkójáde ètò tuntun pẹ̀lú NATO àti àwọn aṣèpinnu ètò-àbò mìíràn láti rìnrìn àjò pẹ̀lúu wọn ohun tí wọ́n lè ṣe láti dáààbòbo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ètò ìlera lásíkò ìṣiṣẹ́.

english: We want them to see that protecting health systems and other critical social institutions is an integral part of their mission.
yoruba: A fẹ́ kí wọ́n rí i wí pé dídáààbò bo ètò ìlera àti àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ mìíràn jẹ́ ọ̀kan pàtàkì lára iṣẹ́ wọn.

english: It's not just about avoiding collateral damage; it's about winning the peace.
yoruba: Kì í ṣe kí ènìyán máa sá fún ìba nǹkan jẹ́ àwọn ológun nìkan; ó jé láti borí pẹ̀lú àlááfíà.

english: But the most important partner we need to engage is you, the American public, and indeed, the world public.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n alájọṣe tó ṣe pàtàkì jùlọ tí a nílò láti bá sọ̀rọ̀ ni ẹ̀yin, ẹ̀yin ènìyan ilẹ̀ America, àti lóòótọ́, ẹ̀yin ènìyàn àgbáyé.

english: Because unless you understand the value of social institutions, like health systems in these fragile settings, you won't support efforts to save them.
yoruba: Nítorí àyàfi tí ẹ bá ní òye ìwúlò àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ àwùjọ, bí ètò ìlera ní àwọn ibùdó ẹlẹgẹ́ wọ̀nyí, ẹ ò ní ṣe àtìlẹyìn fún ìgbìyànjú láti dóòlà wọn.

english: You won't click on that article that talks about "Hey, all those doctors are on the run in country X.
yoruba: Ẹ ò ní gbọ́wọ́lé átíkù yẹn tó ń sọ nípa “Hey, gbogbo àwọn oníṣégùn-òyìnbó yẹn ti ń sá kúrò ní orílẹ̀-ède X.

english: I wonder what that means.
yoruba: Mo wòye ohun tí èyí túmọ̀ sí.

english: I wonder what that means for that health system's ability to, let's say, detect influenza.
yoruba: Mo wòye nǹkan tí ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí fún ìkápá ètò ìlera yẹn láti, ká sọ wí pé, kẹ́fín àrùn-ọlọ́jẹ̀-òpónà-èémí.

english: " "Hmm, it's probably not good.
yoruba: “ “Hmm, bóyá kò dára.

english: " That's what I'd tell you.
yoruba: “ Nǹkan tí màá sọ fún yín nìyẹn.

english: Up on the screen, I've put up my three favorite American institution defenders and builders.
yoruba: Lókè lójú agbòjí, mo ti fi àwọn àwọn ààyò mi mẹ́ta tí wọ́n jẹ́ aláábò tí wọ́n sì kọ́ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ilẹ̀ America.

english: Over here is George C. Marshall, he was the guy that proposed the Marshall Plan to save all of Europe's economic institutions after World War II.
yoruba: Níbí yìí ni George C. Marshall, òun ni ọkùnrin tó dábàá ìpinnu Marshall láti dóóla gbogbo ilé-iṣẹ́ ọrọ̀-ajé ilẹ̀ Europe lẹ́yìn Ogun Àgbáyé II.

english: And this Eleanor Roosevelt.
yoruba: Eleanor Roosevelt nìyí.

english: Her work on human rights really serves as the foundation for all of our international human rights organizations.
yoruba: Iṣẹ́ rẹ̀ lórí ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ-ènìyàn ṣiṣẹ́ gẹ́gẹ́ bi ìpìlẹ̀ fún gbogbo àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ ẹ̀tọ́ ọmọ-ènìyàn wa lágbàyé.

english: Then my big favorite is Ben Franklin, who did many things in terms of creating institutions, but was the midwife of our constitution.
yoruba: Ben Franklin ni ààyò mi tó tóbi jù, tí ó ṣe oríṣiríṣi nǹkan nípa ṣíṣe ìdásílẹ̀ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́, ṣùgbọ́n to jẹ́ agbẹ̀bí ninú ìwé-òfin wa.

english: And I would say to you that these are folks who, when our country was threatened, or our world was threatened, they didn't retreat.
yoruba: Mà á sì sọ fún yín wí pé àwọn wọ̀nyí ni àwọn tí, nígbà tí orílẹ̀-èdè wa wà nínú ewu, tàbí tí ilé-àyé wa wà nínú ewu, wọn ò sá.

english: They didn't talk about building walls.
yoruba: Wọn ò sọ nípa kíkọ́ àwọn ògiri.

english: They talked about building institutions to protect human security, for their generation and also for ours.
yoruba: Wọ́n sọ̀rọ̀ nípa kíkọ́ àwọn ilé-iṣẹ́ láti dáààbò bo ètò-àbo ọmọ ènìyàn, fún ìran wọn àti fún tiwa.

english: And I think our generation should do the same.
yoruba: Mo sì rò wí pé ìran tiwa náà gbọdọ̀ ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀.

english: Thank you.
yoruba: Ẹ ṣeun.

english: Lessons from the 1918 flu
yoruba: Àwọn ẹ̀kọ́ látara àrùn-ọlọ́jẹ̀-ọ̀nà-èémí ọdún 1918.

english: So the first question is, why do we need to even worry about a pandemic threat?
yoruba: Ìbéèrè àkọ́kọ́ ni, kíni ìdí tí a fi nílò láti ronú nípa ewu àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn káríayé?

english: What is it that we're concerned about?
yoruba: Kíni nǹkan náà tí à ń ronú nípa rẹ̀?

english: When I say "we," I'm at the Council on Foreign Relations.
yoruba: Bí mo bá sọ wí pé “àwa”, mo wà ní Àjọ-ìgbìmọ̀ tó ń rí sí àjọṣepọ̀ ilẹ̀-òkèèrè.

english: We're concerned in the national security community, and of course in the biology community and the public health community.
yoruba: A dá lórí àwùjọ ètò-ààbò orílẹ̀-èdè, bẹ́ẹ̀ ni àwùjọ ẹ̀kọ́ nípa ẹ̀dá àti àwùjọ ìlera gbogbogbò.

english: While globalization has increased travel, it's made it necessary that everybody be everywhere, all the time, all over the world.
yoruba: Nígbà tí kárí-ayé tí ṣe àfikún sí ìrìnàjò, ó ti jẹ́ kó rọrùn pé kí gbogbo ènìyàn wà níbi gbogbo, nígbà gbogbo, káàkiri  àgbáyé.

english: And that means that your microbial hitchhikers are moving with you.
yoruba: Ìyẹn túmọ̀ sí wí pé ààrun wíwá ọkọ̀-ọ̀fẹ́ẹ̀ rẹ ti ń tẹ̀lé ẹ.

english: So a plague outbreak in Surat, India becomes not an obscure event, but a globalized event -- a globalized concern that has changed the risk equation.
yoruba: Àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn kan ní Surat, India kò ní jẹ́ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ àìrí, ṣùgbọ́n ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ káríayé -- ìrònú káríayé tó ti ṣe àyípadà iye ewu.

english: Katrina showed us that we cannot completely depend on government to have readiness in hand, to be capable of handling things.
yoruba: Katrina fi hàn wá wí pé a ò lè gbọ́kàn lé ìjọba pátápátá láti wà ní ìmúrasílẹ̀ lọ́gán, láti lè ní ìkápá ìṣàkóso nǹkan.

english: Indeed, an outbreak would be multiple Katrinas at once.
yoruba: Lóòótọ́, àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn kan yóò di ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ Katrina lẹ́ẹ̀kan ṣoṣo.

english: Our big concern at the moment is a virus called H5N1 flu -- some of you call it bird flu -- which first emerged in southern China, in the mid-1990s, but we didn't know about it until 1997.
yoruba: Ìrònu wa tó tóbi jù lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́ yìí ni kòkòrò kan tí wọ́n ń pè ní àrùn-ọlọ́jẹ̀-ọ̀nà-èémí H5N1 -- àwọn kan nínú yín máa ń pè é ní kọ́ọ́lí -- tí ó kọ́kọ́ ṣẹ́yọ ní gúúsù orílẹ̀-ède China, ní àárín 1990, ṣùgbọ́n a ò gbọ́ nípa rẹ̀ àfi ọdún 1997.

english: At the end of last Christmas only 13 countries had seen H5N1.
yoruba: Ní ìparí ọdún Kérésì tó kọjá àwọn orílẹ̀-èdè mẹ́tàlá nìkan ni wọ́n ti rí H5N1.

english: But we're now up to 55 countries in the world, have had this virus emerge, in either birds, or people or both.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n a ti to orílẹ̀-èdè márùn-ún-lé-láàdọ́ta ní àgbáyé báyìí, tí kòkòrò yí ti ṣẹ́yọ, yálà lára ẹranko-abìyẹ́, tàbí ènìyàn tàbí méjéèjì.

english: In the bird outbreaks we now can see that pretty much the whole world has seen this virus except the Americas.
yoruba: Nínú àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn ẹranko-abìyẹ́ náà a lè ri báyìí pé ó fẹ́rẹ̀ẹ́ jẹ́ gbogbo àgbáyé l’ó ti rí kòkòrò yìí àyàfi àwọn ará ilẹ̀ America nìkan.

english: And I'll get into why we've so far been spared in a moment.
yoruba: Màá sì wọnú ìdi rẹ̀ tó fi dáwasí láìpẹ́.

english: In domestic birds, especially chickens, it's 100 percent lethal.
yoruba: Lára àwọn ohun-ọ̀sìn abìyẹ́, pàápàá jùlọ adìyẹ, ìda ogọ́rùn ni ìṣekúpani rẹ̀.

english: It's one of the most lethal things we've seen in circulation in the world in any recent centuries.
yoruba: Ó jẹ́ ọ̀kan lára àwọn nǹkan tó lè ṣekúpani tí a ti rí tó wà káàkiri àgbáyé ní àwọn ọ̀rún-ọdún láìpẹ̀ yìí.

english: And we've dealt with it by killing off lots and lots and lots of chickens, and unfortunately often not reimbursing the peasant farmers with the result that there's cover-up.
yoruba: A ti kojú rẹ̀ pẹ̀lu pípa ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ àwọn adìyẹ, ó sì ṣeni láànú pé lọ́pọ̀ ìgbà wọn kìí sanwó rẹ̀ padà fún àwọn àgbè olókoòwò kékèké pèlú èsì wí pé ìbòjú wà níbẹ̀.

english: It's also carried on migration patterns of wild migratory aquatic birds.
yoruba: Wọ́n tún gbé e lórí bátánì aṣíkiri àwọn ẹyẹ omi ìgbẹ́ tí wọ́n máa ń ṣí kiri.

english: There has been this centralized event in a place called Lake Chenghai, China.
yoruba: Irú ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ ìgbàkóso yìí ti wáyé ní àyè kan tí wọ́n ń pè ní Lake Chenghai, ní orílẹ̀-ède China.

english: Two years ago the migrating birds had a multiple event where thousands died because of a mutation occurring in the virus, which made the species range broaden dramatically.
yoruba: Ní ọdún méjì sẹ́yìn àwọn ẹyẹ aṣíkiri ní ọ̀pọ̀lọpọ̀ ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ níbi tí àwọn ẹgbẹ̀rún ti kú nítorí àyípadà tó ń sẹlẹ̀ sí kòkòrò náà, tó jẹ kí òdiwọ̀n ọ̀wọ́ wọn tóbi sí i bí eré.

english: So that birds going to Siberia, to Europe, and to Africa carried the virus, which had not previously been possible.
yoruba: Kí àwọn ẹyẹ tí wọ́n ń lọ sí Siberia, sí Europe àti sí ilẹ̀ Adúláwọ̀ gbé kòkòrò náà, èyí tí ò ṣe é ṣe tẹ́lẹ̀.

english: We're now seeing outbreaks in human populations -- so far, fortunately, small events, tiny outbreaks, occasional clusters.
yoruba: A wá ń rí àjàkakẹ̀ àrùn náà láàárín àwọn ọmọ-ènìyàn nísiyín -- lọ́wọ́lọ́wọ́, orí báwa ṣé, àwọn ìṣẹ̀lẹ̀ kékèèké, àwọn àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn tó kéré, ìṣùpọ̀ lẹ́ẹ̀kọ̀ọ̀kan.

english: The virus has mutated dramatically in the last two years to form two distinct families, if you will, of the H5N1 viral tree with branches in them, and with different attributes that are worrying.
yoruba: Kòkòrò náà ti yí padà bi eré láàárín ọdún méjì sẹ́yìn láti di ẹbí méjì ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀, tí ẹ bá máa ṣe bẹ́ẹ̀, ti igi kòkòro H5N1 pẹ̀lú àwọn ẹ̀ka nínú wọn, pẹ̀lú àwọn àwòmọ́ ọ̀tọ̀ọ̀tọ̀ tí ò fini lọ́kàn balẹ̀.

english: So what's concerning us?
yoruba: Torí náà kí ló ń mú wa ronú?

english: Well, first of all, at no time in history have we succeeded in making in a timely fashion, a specific vaccine for more than 260 million people.
yoruba: Ó dáa, àkọ́kọ́ ná, kò sí ìgbà kankan nínú ìtàn tí a ṣàṣeyọrí níbi ṣíṣe àkànṣe òògùn àjẹsára lásíkò fún ọ̀tà-lé-nígba ènìyán lé.

english: It's not going to do us very much good in a global pandemic.
yoruba: Kò ní ṣewá ní àǹfààní tó pọ̀ nígbà tí àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn káríayé bá ṣẹ̀.

english: You've heard about the vaccine we're stockpiling.
yoruba: Ẹ ti gbọ́ nípa òògùn àjẹsára tí à ń kó pamọ́ lọ́pọ̀.

english: But nobody believes it will actually be particularly effective if we have a real outbreak.
yoruba: Ṣùgbọ́n kò sẹ́ni tó gbàgbọ́ wí pé yóò ṣiṣẹ́ tí a bá ní àjàkálẹ̀ àrùn tòótọ́.

english: So one thought is: after 9/11, when the airports closed, our flu season was delayed by two weeks.
yoruba: Ìrònú kan ni wí pé: lẹ́yin 9/11, nígbà tí wọ́n ti pápákọ̀ òfuurufú, àsìko àrùn-ọlọ́jẹ̀-ọ̀nà-èémí wa ní ìdádúró fún òsẹ̀ méjì.

english: So the thought is, hey, maybe what we should do is just immediately -- we hear there is H5N1 spreading from human to human, the virus has mutated to be a human-to-human transmitter -- let's shut down the airports.
yoruba: Ìrònú náà ni wí pé, hey, bóyá nǹkan tó yẹ ká ṣe máa jẹ́ lẹ́sẹ̀kẹsẹ̀ -- a gbọ́ pé H5N1 kan wà tó ń ràn látara ènìyàn sí ènìyàn, kòkòrò náà ti yípadà láti di àkóràn ènìyàn sí ènìyàn -- ẹ jẹ́ ká ti pápákò òfuurufú pa.

english: However, huge supercomputer analyses, done of the likely effectiveness of this, show that it won't buy us much time at all.
yoruba: Ẹ̀wẹ̀, ìtúpalẹ̀ ẹ̀rọ-ayárabíàsá alágbára ńlá, tí wọ́n ṣe nípa bí èyí ṣe lágbára sí, fi hàn pé kò ní fún wa ní àsìkò púpọ̀ rárá.
